The conference resulted in agreement upon a comprehensive reorganization of present
agencies in the field designed to build upon the strengths of the present situation a new
edifice better designed to meet the demands of the future. This proposal will be re¬
ferred to the organizations represented in the conference in anticipation that it can be
approved by them and put into operation January 1, 1956.
The plan involves the following major itemsi
^° A reorganization of the present Joint Committee on Educational Television.
The name of this organization will be changed to ThTJoint Council on Educational Tele-
vis ion and its membership will be enlarged to make it fully representative of the educa¬
tional broadcasting movement. Its membership will include, in addition to the present
membership, the Educational Television and Radio Center, representative national
citizens organizations and such other groups as will make it truly representative. It
will serve as the sounding board for the movement, will make such pronouncements as
are desirable from time to time, will lend support to presentations before the FCC and
otherwise will represent the developing educational television and radio movement in
Washington and nationally.
2. The creation of a Policy Committee of this new and reorganized Joint
Council on Educational Television. The Policy Committee will include three ex officio
(voting) members = -the chairman of the Joint Council on Educational Television, the
representative of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters and the
representative of the Educational Television and Radio Center--and two others appointed
at large and on a rotating basis from tile constituent member s of the Council. It is
anticipated that the first at-large members will represent land grant college and national
citizens interests. This committee will have full responsibility for the determination
of policy, the definition of functions, the approval of budget and the appointment of staff
to the Washington office mentioned under (3) below. It will be the duty of this committee
to determine not only what functions are to be served and what services performed by
the Washington office, but also to decide which functions and services now performed
by any Washington agency might better be cared for by one of the other operating
agencies in the field. The committee will determine what is required in the Washington
office to meet the needs of all interested parties including the stations, the NAEB, the
Center and the public. The committee will do everything possible to interpret the
movement to the public. The committee will approve the budget of the Washington office
including support for the Joint Council and will make presentations to the proper agencies
for funds in support of this operation. This committee will also be charged with the
responsibility of a continuing review of general policies in educational broadcasting and
will arrange for such studies as are essential to this end. The chairman of the Joint
Council will serve as chairman of the Policy Committee.
The creation of a single, unified Washington office. All present Washington
operations of the five groups participating in this decision will be closed as of December 31,
1955. This does not mean that either the National Citizens Committee on Educational
Television or the Committee on Television of the American Council on Education will be
dissolved, but only that if either does continue it will do so within the framework of the
